column2: Elizabeth Eliza and the little boys looked at one another, and then hurried back to the house and told their mother.
column3: Elizabeth Eliza and the little boys looked at one another, and then hurried back to the house and told their mother.

column2: The horse was untied, and they all went to ride.
column3: The horse was untied, and they all went to ride.

column2: THE PETERKINS AT HOME.
column3: THE p e t e r k i n s AT HOME.

column2: AT DINNER.
column3: AT DINNER.

column2: ANOTHER little incident occurred in the Peterkin family.
column3: ANOTHER little incident occurred in the Peterkin family.

column2: This was at dinner-time.
column3: This was at dinner time.

column2: They sat down to a dish of boiled ham.
column3: They sat down to a dish of boiled ham.

column2: Now it was a peculiarity of the children of the family, that half of them liked fat, and half liked lean.
column3: Now it was a peculiarity of the children of the family, that half of them liked fat, and half liked lean.

column2: Mr. Peterkin sat down to cut the ham.
column3: mr Peterkin sat down to cut the ham.

column2: But the ham turned out to be a very remarkable one.
column3: But the ham turned out to be a very remarkable one.

column2: The fat and the lean came in separate slices,--first one of lean, than one of fat, then two slices of lean, and so on.
column3: The fat and the lean came in separate slices,--first one of lean, than one of fat, then two slices of lean, and so on.

column2: Mr. Peterkin began as usual by helping the children first, according to their age.
column3: mr Peterkin began as usual by helping the children first, according to their age.

column2: Now Agamemnon, who liked lean, got a fat slice; and Elizabeth Eliza, who preferred fat, had a lean slice.
column3: Now Agamemnon, who liked lean, got a fat slice; and Elizabeth Eliza, who preferred fat, had a lean slice.

column2: Solomon John, who could eat nothing but lean, was helped to fat, and so on.
column3: Solomon john, who could eat nothing but lean, was helped to fat, and so on.

column2: Nobody had what he could eat.
column3: Nobody had what he could eat.

column2: It was a rule of the Peterkin family, that no one should eat any of the vegetables without some of the meat; so now, although the children saw upon their plates apple-sauce and squash and tomato and sweet potato and sour potato, not one of them could eat a mouthful, because not one was satisfied with the meat.
column3: It was a rule of the Peterkin family, that no one should eat any of the vegetables without some of the meat; so now, although the children saw upon their plates apple sauce and squash and tomato and sweet potato and sour potato, not one of them could eat a mouthful, because not one was satisfied with the meat.

column2: Mr. and Mrs. Peterkin, however, liked both fat and lean, and were making a very good meal, when they looked up and saw the children all sitting eating nothing, and looking dissatisfied into their plates.
column3: mr and mrs Peterkin, however, liked both fat and lean, and were making a very good meal, when they looked up and saw the children all sitting eating nothing, and looking dissatisfied into their plates.

column2: What is the matter now? said Mr. Peterkin.
column3: What is the matter now? said mr Peterkin.

column2: But the children were taught not to speak at table.
column3: But the children were taught not to speak at table.

column2: Agamemnon, however, made a sign of disgust at his fat, and Elizabeth Eliza at her lean, and so on, and they presently discovered what was the difficulty.
column3: Agamemnon, however, made a sign of disgust at his fat, and Elizabeth Eliza at her lean, and so on, and they presently discovered what was the difficulty.

column2: What shall be done now? said Mrs. Peterkin.
column3: What shall be done now? said mrs Peterkin.

column2: They all sat and thought for a little while.
column3: They all sat and thought for a little while.

column2: At last said Mrs. Peterkin, rather uncertainly, "Suppose we ask the lady from Philadelphia what is best to be done."
column3: At last said mrs Peterkin, rather uncertainly, "Suppose we ask the lady from Philadelphia what is best to be done."

column2: But Mr. Peterkin said he didn't like to go to her for everything; let the children try and eat their dinner as it was.
column3: But mr Peterkin said he didn't like to go to her for everything; let the children try and eat their dinner as it was.

column2: And they all tried, but they couldn't.
column3: And they all tried, but they couldn't.

column2: Very well, then. said Mr. Peterkin, "let them go and ask the lady from Philadelphia."
column3: Very well, then. said mr Peterkin, "let them go and ask the lady from Philadelphia."

column2: All of us? cried one of the little boys, in the excitement of the moment.
column3: All of us? cried one of the little boys, in the excitement of the moment.

column2: Yes, said Mrs. Peterkin, "only put on your india-rubber boots." And they hurried out of the house.
column3: Yes, said mrs Peterkin, "only put on your india rubber boots." And they hurried out of the house.

column2: The lady from Philadelphia was just going in to her dinner; but she kindly stopped in the entry to hear what the trouble was.
column3: The lady from Philadelphia was just going in to her dinner; but she kindly stopped in the entry to hear what the trouble was.

column2: Agamemnon and Elizabeth Eliza told her all the difficulty, and the lady from Philadelphia said, "But why don't you give the slices of fat to those who like the fat, and the slices of lean to those who like the lean?"
column3: Agamemnon and Elizabeth Eliza told her all the difficulty, and the lady from Philadelphia said, "But why don't you give the slices of fat to those who like the fat, and the slices of lean to those who like the lean?"

column2: They looked at one another.
column3: They looked at one another.

column2: Agamemnon looked at Elizabeth Eliza, and Solomon John looked at the little boys.
column3: Agamemnon looked at Elizabeth Eliza, and Solomon john looked at the little boys.

column2: Why didn't we think of that? said they, and ran home to tell their mother.
column3: Why didn't we think of that? said they, and ran home to tell their mother.

column2: WHY THE PETERKINS HAD A LATE DINNER.
column3: WHY THE p e t e r k i n s HAD A LATE DINNER.

column2: THE trouble was in the dumb-waiter.
column3: THE trouble was in the dumb waiter.

column2: All had seated themselves at the dinner-table, and Amanda had gone to take out the dinner she had sent up from the kitchen on the dumb-waiter.
column3: All had seated themselves at the dinner table, and Amanda had gone to take out the dinner she had sent up from the kitchen on the dumb waiter.

column2: But something was the matter; she could not pull it up.
column3: But something was the matter; she could not pull it up.

column2: There was the dinner, but she could not reach it.
column3: There was the dinner, but she could not reach it.

column2: All the family, in turn, went and tried; all pulled together, in vain; the dinner could not be stirred.
column3: All the family, in turn, went and tried; all pulled together, in vain; the dinner could not be stirred.

column2: No dinner! exclaimed Agamemnon.
column3: No dinner! exclaimed Agamemnon.

column2: I am quite hungry, said Solomon John.
column3: I am quite hungry, said Solomon john.

column2: At last Mr. Peterkin said, "I am not proud.
column3: At last mr Peterkin said, "I am not proud.

column2: I am willing to dine in the kitchen."
column3: I am willing to dine in the kitchen."

column2: This room was below the dining-room.
column3: This room was below the dining room.

column2: All consented to this.
column3: All consented to this.

column2: Each one went down, taking a napkin.
column3: Each one went down, taking a napkin.

column2: The cook laid the kitchen table, put on it her best table-cloth, and the family sat down.
column3: The cook laid the kitchen table, put on it her best table cloth, and the family sat down.

column2: Amanda went to the dumb-waiter for the dinner, but she could not move it down.
column3: Amanda went to the dumb waiter for the dinner, but she could not move it down.

column2: The family were all in dismay.
column3: The family were all in dismay.

column2: There was the dinner, half-way between the kitchen and dining-room, and there were they all hungry to eat it!
column3: There was the dinner, half-way between the kitchen and dining room, and there were they all hungry to eat it!

column2: What is there for dinner? asked Mr. Peterkin.
column3: What is there for dinner? asked mr Peterkin.

column2: Roast turkey, said Mrs. Peterkin.
column3: Roast turkey, said mrs Peterkin.

column2: Mr. Peterkin lifted his eyes to the ceiling.
column3: mr Peterkin lifted his eyes to the ceiling.

column2: Squash, tomato, potato, and sweet potato, Mrs. Peterkin continued.
column3: Squash, tomato, potato, and sweet potato, mrs Peterkin continued.

column2: Sweet potato! exclaimed both the little boys.
column3: Sweet potato! exclaimed both the little boys.

column2: I am very glad now that I did not have cranberry, said Mrs. Peterkin, anxious to find a bright point.
column3: I am very glad now that I did not have cranberry, said mrs Peterkin, anxious to find a bright point.

column2: Let us sit down and think about it, said Mr. Peterkin.
column3: Let us sit down and think about it, said mr Peterkin.

column2: I have an idea, said Agamemnon, after a while.
column3: I have an idea, said Agamemnon, after a while.

column2: Let us hear it, said Mr. Peterkin.
column3: Let us hear it, said mr Peterkin.

column2: Let each one speak his mind.
column3: Let each one speak his mind.

column2: The turkey, said Agamemnon, "must be just above the kitchen door.
column3: The turkey, said Agamemnon, "must be just above the kitchen door.

column2: If I had a ladder and an axe, I could cut away the plastering and reach it."
column3: If I had a ladder and an axe, I could cut away the plastering and reach it."

column2: That is a great idea, said Mrs. Peterkin.
column3: That is a great idea, said mrs Peterkin.

column2: If you think you could do it, said Mr. Peterkin.
column3: If you think you could do it, said mr Peterkin.

column2: Would it not be better to have a carpenter? asked Elizabeth Eliza.
column3: Would it not be better to have a carpenter? asked Elizabeth Eliza.

column2: A carpenter might have a ladder and an axe, and I think we have neither, said Mrs. Peterkin.
column3: A carpenter might have a ladder and an axe, and I think we have neither, said mrs Peterkin.

column2: A carpenter!	A carpenter!
column3: true

column2: A carpenter!" exclaimed the rest.
column3: A carpenter!" exclaimed the rest.

column2: It was decided that Mr. Peterkin, Solomon John, and the little boys should go in search of a carpenter.
column3: It was decided that mr Peterkin, Solomon john, and the little boys should go in search of a carpenter.

column2: Agamemnon proposed that, meanwhile, he should go and borrow a book; for he had another idea.
column3: Agamemnon proposed that, meanwhile, he should go and borrow a book; for he had another idea.

column2: This affair of the turkey, he said, "reminds me of those buried cities that have been dug out,--Herculaneum, for instance."
column3: This affair of the turkey, he said, "reminds me of those buried cities that have been dug out,--Herculaneum, for instance."

column2: Oh, yes, interrupted Elizabeth Eliza, "and Pompeii."
column3: Oh, yes, interrupted Elizabeth Eliza, "and Pompeii."

column2: Yes, said Agamemnon, "they found there pots and kettles.
column3: Yes, said Agamemnon, "they found there pots and kettles.

column2: Now, I should like to know how they did it; and I mean to borrow a book and read.
column3: Now, I should like to know how they did it; and I mean to borrow a book and read.

column2: I think it was done with a pickaxe."
column3: I think it was done with a pickaxe."

column2: So the party set out.
column3: So the party set out.

column2: But when Mr. Peterkin reached the carpenter's shop, there was no carpenter to be found there.
column3: But when mr Peterkin reached the carpenter's shop, there was no carpenter to be found there.

column2: He must be at his house, eating his dinner, suggested Solomon John.
column3: He must be at his house, eating his dinner, suggested Solomon john.

column2: Happy man, exclaimed Mr. Peterkin, "he has a dinner to eat!"
column3: Happy man, exclaimed mr Peterkin, "he has a dinner to eat!"

column2: They went to the carpenter's house, but found he had gone out of town for a day's job.
column3: They went to the carpenter's house, but found he had gone out of town for a day's job.

column2: But his wife told them that he always came back at night to ring the nine-o'clock bell.
column3: But his wife told them that he always came back at night to ring the nine o'clock bell.

column2: We must wait till then, said Mr. Peterkin, with an effort at cheerfulness.
column3: We must wait till then, said mr Peterkin, with an effort at cheerfulness.

column2: At home he found Agamemnon reading his book, and all sat down to hear of Herculaneum and Pompeii.
column3: At home he found Agamemnon reading his book, and all sat down to hear of Herculaneum and Pompeii.

column2: Time passed on, and the question arose about tea.
column3: Time passed on, and the question arose about tea.

column2: Would it do to have tea when they had had no dinner?
column3: Would it do to have tea when they had had no dinner?

column2: A part of the family thought it would not do; the rest wanted tea.
column3: A part of the family thought it would not do; the rest wanted tea.

column2: I suppose you remember the wise lady of Philadelphia, who was here not long ago, said Mr. Peterkin.
column3: I suppose you remember the wise lady of Philadelphia, who was here not long ago, said mr Peterkin.

column2: Oh, yes, said Mrs. Peterkin.
column3: Oh, yes, said mrs Peterkin.

column2: Let us try to think what she would advise us, said Mr. Peterkin.
column3: Let us try to think what she would advise us, said mr Peterkin.

column2: I wish she were here, said Elizabeth Eliza.
column3: I wish she were here, said Elizabeth Eliza.

column2: I think, said Mr. Peterkin, "she would say, let them that want tea have it; the rest can go without."
column3: I think, said mr Peterkin, "she would say, let them that want tea have it; the rest can go without."

column2: So they had tea, and, as it proved, all sat down to it.
column3: So they had tea, and, as it proved, all sat down to it.

column2: But not much was eaten, as there had been no dinner.
column3: But not much was eaten, as there had been no dinner.

column2: When the nine-o'clock bell was heard, Agamemnon, Solomon John, and the little boys rushed to the church, and found the carpenter.
column3: When the nine o'clock bell was heard, Agamemnon, Solomon john, and the little boys rushed to the church, and found the carpenter.

column2: They asked him to bring a ladder, axes and pickaxe.
column3: They asked him to bring a ladder, axes and pickaxe.

column2: As he felt it might be a case of fire, he brought also his fire-buckets.
column3: As he felt it might be a case of fire, he brought also his fire buckets.

column2: When the matter was explained to him, he went into the dining-room, looked into the dumb-waiter, untwisted a cord, and arranged the weight, and pulled up the dinner.
column3: When the matter was explained to him, he went into the dining room, looked into the dumb waiter, untwisted a cord, and arranged the weight, and pulled up the dinner.

column2: There was a family shout.
column3: There was a family shout.

column2: The trouble was in the weight, said the carpenter.
column3: The trouble was in the weight, said the carpenter.

column2: That is why it is called a dumb-waiter, Solomon John explained to the little boys.
column3: That is why it is called a dumb waiter, Solomon john explained to the little boys.

column2: The dinner was put upon the table.
column3: The dinner was put upon the table.

column2: Mrs. Peterkin frugally suggested that they might now keep it for the next day, as to-day was almost gone, and they had had tea.
column3: mrs Peterkin frugally suggested that they might now keep it for the next day, as to day was almost gone, and they had had tea.

column2: But nobody listened.
column3: But nobody listened.

column2: All sat down to the roast turkey; and Amanda warmed over the vegetables.
column3: All sat down to the roast turkey; and Amanda warmed over the vegetables.

column2: Patient waiters are no losers, said Agamemnon.
column3: Patient waiters are no losers, said Agamemnon.

column2: THE PETERKINS' SUMMER JOURNEY.
column3: THE p e t e r k i n s' SUMMER JOURNEY.

column2: IN fact, it was their last summer's journey--for it had been planned then; but there had been so many difficulties, it had been delayed.
column3: IN fact, it was their last summer's journey-for it had been planned then; but there had been so many difficulties, it had been delayed.
